data.title: Conflict: a Distributed Condition: Contemporary War Ecologies
data.desc:
Conflict is not an exception or an isolated event — it is a constant condition running through society. It is not limited to war or explicit clashes: it emerges within collective life as friction, as a continuous confrontation between competing needs, systems, and visions.
It is not a punctual episode but a latent and distributed condition. It takes on asymmetric, often invisible forms, embedded in cultural practices, social relations, and infrastructures. Its logic is not confined to violence: it also structures coexistence, shaping who holds privilege and who is pushed to the margins.
Exploring distributed conflicts means reading the present as a field where techniques of offense multiply and blur into the infrastructures society depends on. The goal is to generate critical devices, scenarios, and questions that probe the ambiguous nature of conflict as a diffuse condition in a post-territorial age.

data.title: Cognitive Dissonance
data.desc: It's a universal psychological mechanism: we all experience small conflicts between thoughts, values, and actions every day. It explains a person's choices and behaviors, attitudes that can sometimes even seem irrational. It shows that we don't always make logical decisions: we choose solutions that reduce psychological distress, even at the expense of objective coherence. This explains phenomena such as polarization, fake news, and personal justifications.

data.title: Neuropolitics
data.desc: Neuroscience, AI, and politics are at the center of contemporary debate. It's a hot and plausible topic. It implies a strong cognitive conflict: more knowledge and transparency on the one hand, more surveillance and manipulation on the other. It opens the door to tangible devices (bracelets, helmets, pills, algorithms), which can be prototyped in credible but also disturbing ways. Politics affects everyone, and a project that questions freedom of thought and voting generates immediate discussion.

data.title: Learning
data.desc:
The learning phase is crucial for cognitive development and conflict: Children actively construct their cognitive schemas; it is during this phase that lasting ways of dealing with dissonance are defined.
Exposing children to cognitive discrepancies creates a state of imbalance that pushes them toward accommodating new schemas. 
Working in groups with different ideas exposes children to their first meaningful experiences of cognitive disagreement. These differences influence whether conflict is productive or counterproductive.
Parents transmit values, explanations, and strategies (explicit and implicit) that shape how children deal with dissonance.

data.title: Cognitive Hedonia
data.desc:
Mark Fisher coined the term "depressive hedonia" to describe a modern paradox: people who obsessively seek pleasure but never get real satisfaction from it.
Constant stimulation from the digital world overactivates our "wanting" system (dopamine) but makes our "pleasure" system (opioids) less sensitive. Result: we keep seeking rewards but never feel truly satisfied.
The mental conflict is frustrating: people understand that scrolling social media or consuming endless entertainment is pointless, but they can't stop. Fisher calls this "powerless reflexivity" - you know what you should do but remain trapped in behaviors that harm you.
This is a specific consequence of late capitalism that has created an environment of constant stimulation never seen before in human history, where seeking gratification becomes compulsive but never satisfying.

data.title: Hypnosis
data.desc: Hypnosis shows that our thinking isn't as stable as we think. When hypnotized, people accept ideas they would normally reject. This lets us create mental conflicts in a controlled way to see how the mind deals with them. Surprisingly, these conflicts can actually help people change in ways that wouldn't be possible otherwise. But this makes us wonder: if suggestions can so easily get past our logical thinking, how much control do we really have over our daily decisions?

data.title: Devil shift
data.desc:
The devil shift reflects a universal bias: we tend to see opponents as more hostile, threatening, and powerful than they really are, seeking evidence to confirm this view while ignoring anything that challenges it.
The angel shift is the opposite bias: we idealize allies, seeing them as more virtuous, trustworthy, and capable than they actually are, while overlooking their flaws or mistakes.

data.title: Cognitive overload
data.desc:
It has been established that as cognitive overload increases, so does the feeling of anxiety and avoidance when it comes to making decisions. This can trigger decision fatigue.
The quality of decisions deteriorates as cognitive resources are depleted; ultimately, this leads to outright decision avoidance or a tendency to delegate choices, even important ones. When the amount of information exceeds the threshold of available cognitive resources, they begin to compete with each other.

data.title: First review
data.desc:
The review examined the concepts of decision fatigue, devil shift, and depressive hedonia, highlighting their relevance to psychological and perceptual processes. Particular attention was given to the role of intrapsychic mechanisms in facilitating empathy, with cognitive dissonance identified as a valuable framework for interpreting marketing strategies.
Methodologically, the systematic use of “what if” questions was recommended to explore potential scenarios and their implications. 
In the construction of mood boards, the inclusion of real-world elements—such as tools, materials, and abstract signs—was emphasized as a means of eliciting and representing core aspects of the investigated concept.
Conflict includes organized and perceived violence, and prototypes must feel real rather than exist materially.

data.title: Devil shift and cancel culture
data.desc:
Applying the devil shift to an individual means concentrating all blame on them, reducing complexity to a single perspective. The person becomes the “absolute villain,” even if not necessarily so.
With social media, this dynamic intensifies: a single case can trigger collective judgment, often fuelled by past episodes or statements, even if now irrelevant.
Rarely do we ask whether we too might have acted like the “cancelled” person. Group pressure reduces critical capacity, fostering conformity and flattening judgment.
Those targeted are labelled and marginalised, raising questions about inclusion and social responsibility: are we truly as free from prejudice as we believe?
The project encourages seeing things from the perspective of the cancelled person, building empathy and breaking down stigmatisation, so their complexity and humanity are not reduced to a single label.

data.title: Cognitive Hedonia
data.desc:
We use social media because it gives us pleasure and releases dopamine. On one hand, we know we’re wasting time and engaging in a fleeting search for gratification, yet we can’t seem to disconnect. This mechanism resembles an addictive pattern.
In this context, we could imagine a kind of “drug” that provides exactly what we’re seeking—the immediate pleasure and dopamine release. That way, we wouldn’t need to spend time on social media to entertain ourselves, because our brains have already received what they want. But would it truly be satisfying?
This approach could free up the time we usually feel we lack to do what we really want. And if we do have that free time, will we actually use it as we intend?

data.title: Decision fatigue and vote
data.desc:
In a world where voter interest is declining and turnout is at historic lows, who has truly shaped the system we live in—those who voted, or those who abstained?
Abstaining and leaving decisions to the majority can be a symptom of decision fatigue. People are often unmotivated to inform themselves, showing little interest—even though the outcomes affect them on multiple levels.
This creates a cognitive conflict: political choices are complex, ambiguous, and full of imperfect alternatives. The inability to decide without discomfort leads to the simplest solution: not deciding at all. Abstention thus acts as a strategy to reduce cognitive noise.
But who really decided our system—the voters or the abstainers? And what if the tools meant to guide our choices—polls, surveys, tests—actually alienate us, flattening our critical and civic engagement?
Non-choice is, in fact, a choice. Even if we believe that abstaining carries no consequences, it does—and it impacts both the system and those who abstain.

data.title: Cognitive Hedonia 2
data.desc:
In a world that no longer offers stable pleasure or gratification from traditional sources of entertainment, the individual experiences a profound cognitive conflict: to feel authentic sensations, they turn to content that, rationally, should provoke repulsion—true crime, violent news, gore. The mind is thus forced to reconcile two irreconcilable poles: the pleasure derived from intense emotional stimulation and the moral awareness that this pleasure stems from the suffering of others.
It becomes imperative to show how the need to “feel something” is captured and exploited by the market of pain, prompting the audience to reflect on the human and ethical cost of turning others’ suffering into entertainment.

data.title: Second review
data.desc:
Reflect: What conflicts does this theme create?
What issues does it cause in today’s society? Provide concrete examples.
Project Concept:
What kind of project could emerge from a theme like this? Think about the message you want to convey concretely through the project.
Moodboard:
Translate the concept into visuals through examples (e.g., images of Trump, Netflix).

data.title: Third review
data.desc: The general themes are solid, fertile, and interesting, but the theme of voting doesn’t fit well with the concept of decision fatigue, since voter abstention stems more from lack of interest than from too many choices. The “what if” questions are too generic and should be made more specific. In the moodboard, some images are too abstract and don’t clearly relate to the theme, while the ones showing concrete cases or the organizations chosen for the scenario work better. It’s recommended to introduce a small initial change that leads to a more distant and engaging scenario.

data.title: Case study 1 - Devil shift
data.desc: People tend to avoid cognitive dissonance, which is the discomfort that arises when new facts or ideas conflict with their existing beliefs. Even in the face of objective evidence and data, people often prefer to ignore or rationalize information that challenges their beliefs rather than change their minds. This psychological mechanism makes it difficult to alter opinions and explains why facts alone rarely suffice to change deeply held beliefs.
links: Do facts have the power to change our minds?

data.title: Case study 1 - Decision fatigue
data.desc: The study by Danziger et al. (2011) analyzed over 1,100 parole decisions made by Israeli judges over 10 months, finding that decisions varied greatly depending on the time of day. At the beginning of sessions, about 65% of requests were granted, but the percentage dropped to almost zero before breaks and rose again after meals.  This phenomenon was attributed to decision fatigue: when judges were mentally exhausted, they tended to choose the simplest and most conservative option—denying parole

data.title: Case study 1 - depressive hedonia
data.desc: The case study examines how habitual exposure to violent media contributes to emotional desensitization.  Findings indicate that individuals with higher exposure to violent media exhibit reduced physiological arousal (as measured by skin conductance level) and lower anxiety when viewing violent scenes, yet report greater pleasure and show faster activation of aggressive thoughts.  This desensitization effect appears to be specific to violent content and is not observed in response to sad or humorous scenes.
links: This study examined the links between desensitiz...

data.title: Case study 2 - Devil shift
data.desc: The “Devil Shift” in political science describes how, in intense conflicts, actors tend to see opponents as more powerful and malevolent than they are. It involves attributing negative motives, judging behavior harshly, overestimating opponents’ influence, and underestimating one’s own. Greater ideological distance amplifies this effect, which reinforces conflicts and hinders cooperation.

The study, based on nine cases in Switzerland, shows that the Devil Shift is stronger among interest groups, political parties, and powerful actors compared to state officials or weaker actors. Additionally, the Devil Shift is more pronounced in processes involving socio-economic issues. The data confirm that the perceived “malevolence” dimension is more widespread than the perceived power dimension.

data.title: Case study 2 - depressive hedonia
data.desc: In recent years, true crime has become a mass phenomenon across series, podcasts, and social media. However, behind the fascination with real crime lies a risk: overexposure to violent content can increase anxiety, paranoia, and stress—especially among young people, who struggle to maintain emotional distance.  Experts warn that while watching true crime is not inherently harmful, excessive consumption can distort one’s perception of reality and personal safety.
links: Gli effetti del True crime sul nostro cervello -...
Negli ultimi 10 anni, il true crime ha assunto un’imp...

data.title: Case study 3 - depressive hedonia
data.desc: The study examines how exposure to violent media influences individual and collective psychology regarding crime and aggression. Repeated exposure can lead to emotional desensitization, greater acceptance of aggression, reduced empathy for victims, and a distorted view of violence as normal or acceptable. It also emphasizes the media’s role in shaping public perceptions of justice, policy responses, and social attitudes toward violence.

data.title: case study 4 - depressive hedonia
data.desc: It analyzes the boom of the true crime genre between 2018 and 2019, attributed both to the desire for strong emotions and morbid curiosity, and to the need to understand the darker side of human nature and society.  The ethical dilemma of voyeurism and the sensationalization of suffering is also discussed.
links: An fMRI investigation of emotional engage...
The long-standing rationalist tradition in moral psy...

data.title: Case study 5 - depressive hedonia
data.desc: Repeated exposure to negative news can lead to emotional desensitization, reduced empathy, and weaker moral judgments—a phenomenon known as the “moral repetition effect.” Doomscrolling worsens this effect, potentially causing apathy, emotional fatigue, and lower motivation to address injustices. Mindful media use, critical thinking, and digital breaks can help preserve moral sensitivity.
links: The More News Headlines We See, the...
Constant exposure to negative news can numb...

data.title: Case study 2 - decision fatigue
data.desc: Case study on judges, scientific journal editors, students, and healthcare professionals.  The study highlights how decision fatigue leads to more impulsive choices, reliance on cognitive shortcuts, and poorer performance—especially under conditions of stress, complexity, or repetitive decision-making.

Somatic Marker Hypothesis (Damasio)  Summary: Damasio proposed that “somatic markers” (bodily sensations linked to emotions) help narrow down and evaluate options in complex decisions—a mechanism through which emotion facilitates quick and adaptive decision-making. This theory has been supported by neuropsychological and neuroimaging studies, but it has also been discussed and criticized. Nonetheless, it remains one of the most influential frameworks connecting emotion and choice.

data.title: Fourth Review
data.desc:
We should propose something that emphasizes the conflict — something that clearly defines the type of subject, the context, and the dynamics at play. The cognitive bias of the devil shift tends to fade away, but it needs to be brought back into focus. How do we imagine this as a staging?
The reduction of conflict already leads us into a scenario filled with too many “what ifs.”

data.title: Panopticon
data.desc:
In the age of mass surveillance and commodified data, we are all constantly watched.
Our devices, online presence, and even physical movements have become assets owned by corporations and governments—a digital panopticon without consent or awareness.

The machine’s invisible gaze monitors and disciplines us, turning Internet users into lifelong prisoners.
At once observer and observed, we inhabit a state of alienation—half human, half data.
A warning about how invisible control has become, and how numb we are to the loss of our privacy.

data.title: Fifth review
data.desc:
Hedonia: the project currently relies too heavily on the idea of “simulation,” which risks diluting the real intensity of the experience.
What truly matters is designing a situation where the user is genuinely and emotionally involved.
We should focus on how the conflict is activated and felt, rather than on constructing a complex device or system. The experience itself — how it unfolds and engages the participant — is what gives the project meaning.

The concept of the devil shift must be reframed as a cognitive conflict: who silences whom, and for what reason?
This shift helps us return to the human level of perception and agency.
The project’s strength lies in its storytelling — the ability to create resonance through familiar contexts, subtle narratives, and everyday situations that feel real but are carefully constructed.

The guiding principle is simplicity.
The experience should not be overcomplicated with layers of simulation or political overtones, but rather aim to provoke reflection and awareness through clarity, tension, and emotional engagement.

data.title: Sixth review
data.desc:
The goal is to follow a clear, logical process to understand how emotional security can be built and sustained.
At this stage, the focus should be on completely removing cognitive conflict, emphasizing instead the mechanisms that help prevent it.

It’s important not to get fixated on the idea of “silencing”, so as not to restrict the conceptual space or creative possibilities.
The guiding question becomes: what forms of emotional security can be activated to prevent or neutralize cognitive conflict?
From here, we can imagine a device — physical or conceptual — designed to protect and resolve conflict, creating a sense of stability and reassurance.
In parallel, it’s essential to define the brand’s visual and conceptual identity: researching companies or case studies that either perform similar actions or embody a tone of voice consistent with the type of communication we envision.

data.title: Cognitive security
data.desc:
What if we shifted the focus from silencing others to silencing our own thoughts?
When we perceive a trigger — through a certain frequency or noise — the thought could be blocked, not replaced, effectively stopping cognitive conflict before it arises.
This action would leave space for reflection: is it a protective mechanism, or a subtle form of self-censorship? The ambiguity remains open.
Keywords: Trigger, Overstimulation, Sound frequencies, Emptiness, Detachment, Isolation, Protection of one's thoughts, Shutdown / freeze, Linearity

data.title: Review
data.desc:
The project explores how silencing can itself become a form of cognitive dissonance — or how a system might transform silence into dissonance rather than eliminating it.
The aim is to reverse the idea of cognitive dissonance, treating it not as a cause but as a result of conflict, shifting the focus from the personal to the collective level.

Through conceptual exercises like Crazy 8, the work imagines objects or devices that create playful tensions between silence and perception — an experience of “Cognitive Cancelling”, a kind of cognitive deprivation that transforms messages instead of erasing them.
At the core lies a simple idea: every conflict stems from a distortion of reality — an emotional bias that triggers discomfort.
The challenge is to design a tone of voice, message, and communicative mechanism that can reveal this inner distortion.

data.title: Cognitive security review
data.desc:
The project explores the idea of “switching off our thoughts”, using everyday behaviors like scrolling Instagram as a metaphor for cognitive disengagement.
It combines concepts such as spatial audio, meditation apps like Headspace, and devices that distort perception, to create an experiential scenario where users reflect on their inner dynamics.

The focus is on building a specific scenario from a “what if”, which defines both the product and the project’s identity. Storytelling is key, with metaphors like natural filters (mussels or clams) illustrating the concept of filtering or controlling thoughts.

Ultimately, the scenario and narrative serve to define the branding and purpose: why would users want to turn off their thoughts, and what does the project reveal about human perception and behavior?

data.title: Research on social isolation, socio-cultural role of seashells and sound
data.desc: Expansion on the research needed to make the narrative context more grounded and based on actual findings, linking both visual metaphors and means to effectively communicate the concept through a measurable output.

Il problema è strutturale ed è per tanto necessario riprendere tutto dall'inizio. L'isolamento è arrivato come cosa collaterale rispetto al contesto pensato ma diventa alla fine la manifestazione + concreta del conflitto che abbiamo quindi deve essere reso centrale, manca una chiave di lettura critica che sia realmente interessante

data.title: rifacimento totale concept
data.desc: L'isolamento viene concepito come soluzione al conflitto ma anche come progresso naturale della mente umana che si sta adattando a una nuova società individualista, autoriferita, e in cui la mente può prosperare solo quando è completamente da sola e lontana dal prossimo come l'eden: un posto secluso che si evolve solo su se stesso apice del piacere e della beatitudine che si perde col contatto con ciò che sta all'esterno.

data.title: Organic brand identity concept
data.desc: Initial hypotheses for a possible branding direction draw inspiration from the sea, specifically the shell, which acts as an organism that clears the water. This serves as a metaphor for the product's function in clarifying and protecting the mind. The preliminary concepts for the brandmark are significantly influenced by Japanese tech brands, aiming to merge an organic yet professional aesthetic. The identity integrates further synthetic elements to achieve the desired look and feel, including metal, transparency, and paper embossing.

data.title: Organic brand identity concept
data.desc: Initial hypotheses for a possible branding direction draw inspiration from the sea, specifically the shell, which acts as an organism that clears the water. This serves as a metaphor for the product's function in clarifying and protecting the mind. The preliminary concepts for the brandmark are significantly influenced by Japanese tech brands, aiming to merge an organic yet professional aesthetic. The identity integrates further synthetic elements to achieve the desired look and feel, including metal, transparency, and paper embossing.

data.title: Earcuff output ideas
data.desc: Initial sketches feature an output that combines the referenced organic shapes with the concept of shells, specifically those through which one might hear calming sounds, replicating the experience of actual seashells. The proposed form would take the shape of a metallic earcuff.

data.title: First sea-inspired branding proposal
data.desc: First proposal of brand identity for a product named "Mamoru".

data.title: Second brand identity conceptualisation
data.desc: A second brand identity proposal has been developed. While retaining the sea and organic structures as foundational elements, a new visual component, 'blur,' was introduced. This element is intended to signify a barrier between the internal and external environments, conveying a sense of unreachability.

data.title: forma output
